title-group.article-title: The Use of the Harmonic Scalpel Versus Knot Tying for Modified Radical Neck Dissection

author-notes.corresp: Eren Berber, Division of Endocrine Surgery, Endocrinology and Metabolism Institute, Cleveland Clinic, 9500 Euclid Avenue/F20, Cleveland, OH 44195, USA Email: berbere@ccf.org

abstract.p: Background. Although the utility of the harmonic scalpel (HS) in thyroidectomy has been extensively demonstrated, there is little experience regarding its use for neck dissections. Methods. Within 10 years, 119 patients underwent modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for thyroid cancer. In 51 patients, MRND was performed using conventional knot tying and in 68 using the HS. The number of lymph nodes (LNs) removed, operative time, estimated blood loss (EBL), drain output, duration of the drainage, and complications were compared for 47 patients undergoing first-time unilateral MRND without concomitant additional surgical procedures. Results. The number of LNs removed, operative time, duration of drainage, and rate of lymphatic leak were similar between groups. For the HS group, EBL (5 ± 3 vs 32 ± 10; P = .006) and drain output on postoperative day 1 (51.7 ± 6.2 vs 78.9 ± 11.9; P = .02) and at 1 week (6.1 ± 1.2 vs 10.2 ± 1.8, respectively; P = .03) were significantly less. Conclusion. Despite the limitations of its retrospective nature, this study shows that the HS reduces EBL and the amount of lymphatic drainage compared to knot tying after MRND.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Thyroid carcinoma is the most common endocrine malignancy in the United States,1 and metastases to the cervical lymph nodes (LNs) are seen in 20% to 50% of the patients.2-4 Surgical resection of cervical LN metastases may reduce the risk of recurrence and possible mortality.4

Since its first description by Crile5 in 1906, neck dissection has evolved from the classic radical procedure to modified radical neck dissection (MRND), in which the sternocleidomastoid muscle, the spinal accessory nerve, and the internal jugular vein are preserved.6 Nevertheless, there has been no significant change in the conduct of the operation over the last century, other than incorporation of monopolar and bipolar electrocautery in addition to knot tying.7,8 The harmonic scalpel (HS) uses high-frequency mechanical energy to cut and coagulate tissue simultaneously.9 After the initial experience in abdominal surgery demonstrating reduced operative time and complications,10-12 the utility of the HS was assessed in thyroid surgery by multiple authors.9,13-16 The HS was shown to shorten the operative time in thyroidectomy compared with conventional knot tying.9,17,18 However, the experience with neck dissection is limited. To our knowledge, there are only 2 studies in the literature describing the use of the HS for neck dissection19,20 and none focusing on patients who undergo MRND alone for thyroid cancer.

We have been using the HS for thyroidectomies and neck dissections over the past decade. In this retrospective study, our hypothesis was that use of the HS could shorten operative time and decrease postoperative drainage after MRND, compared with knot tying.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Between January 2000 and December 2010, 119 patients underwent modified lateral neck dissection at the Division of Endocrine Surgery at the Cleveland Clinic. Among them, 47 patients underwent unilateral MRND, 32 patients underwent repeat limited neck dissection, and 40 patients had MRND with additional concomitant surgical procedures performed, including thyroidectomy (n = 32), parathyroid autotransplantation (n = 7), and bilateral neck dissection (n = 1). Overall, the HS was used in 68 of these cases and conventional knot tying in 51 (Table 1). For homogeneity between groups, statistical comparisons were performed for the former 47 patients undergoing first-time unilateral MRND without concomitant additional surgical procedures. The choice between the HS and knot tying depended on surgeon preference and availability of equipment.

sec.p: Clinical data were extracted from a prospectively maintained institutional review board–approved database and included age, gender, BMI, pathology, size and number of LNs removed, operative time, estimated blood loss (EBL), complications, drain output on postoperative day (POD) 1 and at the time of removal, and duration of drainage (Table 2). Pathological review was the same for all cases and done by experienced neck pathologists. EBL was calculated by the anesthesiologist using the volume recorded in the suction canister at the end of the case, by subtracting the volume of irrigation. Surgeon experience was quantified based on the years of endocrine surgical practice at the onset of the study.

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: All procedures were performed by 1 of the 4 endocrine surgeons under endotracheal general anesthesia. The patient was positioned supine on the operating room table, and the neck was extended and slightly tilted to the ipsilateral side. Preoperative neck ultrasound was performed prior to making the incision. A transverse neck incision was used, centered on the midportion of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. A standard MRND was performed by removal of the lymphatic tissue at levels II, III, IV, and V. During the procedure, the carotid artery, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve, phrenic nerve, and accessory nerve were dissected and preserved. Hemostasis was obtained with knot tying in the conventional group and with the HS in the other group. A 7-French Jackson-Pratt drain was placed in all patients.

sec.title: Follow-up
sec.p: All patients were discharged home on POD 1. Drain output was measured by the nursing staff and recorded into patient charts. The patients were seen in the office for drain removal at PODs 5 to 7, and drains were removed if 24-hour output was less than 50 cc and did not have evidence of a lymphatic leak.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Data were analyzed using JMP software version 9.0.0 (SAS, Cary, NC) and presented as mean ± standard error of the mean for normally distributed continuous variables. Analyses were performed using the t test, χ2 test, and univariate and multivariate regression analyses. Statistical significance was reached at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Among the patients who underwent unilateral MRND without additional surgical procedures, both the HS and knot-tying groups were comparable regarding clinical and demographic features. Operative time was similar between the HS and knot-tying groups (209 ± 15 vs 212 ± 12 minutes, respectively; P = .45). EBL was less in the HS compared with the knot-tying group (5 ± 3 vs 32 ± 10 cc, respectively; P = .006; Table 2). When the operative time was compared for individual surgeons, there was a time reduction of 12 to 40 minutes with the use of the HS when compared with knot tying.

Drain output on POD 1 and at 1 week was significantly less for the HS versus the knot-tying group (51.7 ± 6.2 and 6.1 ± 1.2 cc vs 78.9 ± 11.9 and 10.2 ± 1.8, respectively; Table 2). There were no intraoperative complications in either group, and postoperative morbidity rates were similar, including a total of 4 cases of postoperative lymphatic leaks (2 in the HS and 2 in the knot-tying group; P = .52), which required a second operation for repair. Overall, in the total number of 119 patients, lymphatic leak was seen in 4 patients, including 2 in the HS and 2 in the knot -tying group. All these leaks were related to branches of the thoracic duct in the inferior left neck. There were no bleeding, septic, or nerve complications.

On univariate analysis, the number of LNs removed affected operative time (P = .002; Table 3). With an even distribution of surgeons in the 2 groups (P = .51), multivariate analysis showed that surgeon experience and the number of LNs removed were independent predictors of operative time (Table 4).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this retrospective study, we compared conventional knot tying versus the HS in patients undergoing MRND. Within the limitations of the study, EBL and drainage was less in the HS group, with lymphatic leak rates similar to knot tying. We did not demonstrate any difference in operating time because multiple physicians were involved and the number of LNs retrieved was different. On multivariate analysis, we demonstrated that the experience of the surgeon and number of LNs removed were independent predictors of operative time for MRND. As the interest to use the HS in various surgical procedures increases, we believe that our experience will provide an initial insight regarding the value of the HS for neck dissections. Based on our favorable experience, we are currently using the HS routinely for these procedures.

Initial experience with the HS in neck surgery began with thyroidectomies. In 2002, our group compared the HS with the conventional knot-tying technique for vessel ligation in 171 patients undergoing either lobectomy or total thyroidectomy. Our results demonstrated that use of the HS was safe and shortened operative time by almost 30 minutes compared with the conventional technique.9

In another study, Shemen14 investigated at the utility of the HS by analyzing 105 patients who underwent thyroidectomy and reported that the HS was superior to conventional techniques in terms of surgical outcomes. The study showed that use of the HS shortened the operative time by 30 to 50 minutes, and the operative blood loss was significantly less in the HS group compared with the conventional group. So far, several other investigators have also shown significant advantages of the HS in thyroid surgery in terms of operative time17,21 and complication rate.18,22

To our knowledge, there are only 2 studies in the literature that focus on the utility of the HS for neck dissection. Miccoli et al20 compared the use of the HS in a group of 37 patients who underwent total thyroidectomy and lateral neck dissection with a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma. This study showed that operative time for lateral lymphadenectomy was significantly lower in the HS versus the conventional group (mean ± standard deviation = 24 ± 8.9 vs 35.7 ± 8.0 minutes, respectively). Moreover, they noticed a lower volume at 24 hours and overall shorter duration of lymphatic drainage in the HS group. Subsequently, Walen et al19 showed the impact of the HS in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma that required selective neck dissection (levels I-IV). They demonstrated that the HS significantly reduced intraoperative blood loss but had no effect on operative time, postoperative drain output, or complication rate. To our knowledge, there is no study in the literature that compares the HS with the conventional knot-tying technique in patients undergoing MRND alone.

In our study, in contrast to the data on thyroidectomies, there was no difference in operative times between the 2 groups. This is in contrast to the study by Miccoli et al,20 which reported a shorter operative time with the use of the HS. We demonstrated that operative time depends on the experience of the surgeon and the number of LNs removed, and therefore, we believe that future studies controlling these variables are necessary to investigate the effect of the HS on operating time in MRND. In fact, when we redid the comparisons for individual surgeons, there was a time reduction of 12 to 40 minutes with use of the HS when compared with knot tying; however, the sample size was small. There was no difference in operative time in the study by Walen et al19 either. However, in this study, the neck dissections were selective and not done for thyroid cancer.

In accordance with the other 2 studies in the literature, we demonstrated a lower drain output on POD 1 and at 1 week with the HS versus knot tying. We hypothesize that the decrease with the HS in lymphatic drainage is related to the fact that small lymphatic ducts are sealed with the HS but not with electrocautery. We still had 2 lymphatic leaks that required a second operation in each group. In all these cases, the leak was related to branches of the thoracic duct in the left inferior neck.

There are reports in the literature documenting the safety of the HS for sealing the thoracic duct. In one of these studies, Kajiyama et al23 demonstrated the feasibility of sealing the thoracic duct on surgical specimens of 27 patients by using the HS. In this study, they recorded the bursting pressure after one end of each vessel was sealed using the HS. As a result, they verified that the mean bursting pressure of the thoracic duct was high enough to support the clinical use of the HS to seal lymphatic structures (P < .001). In another study, Nakayama et al24 showed the effectiveness of the HS for sealing the thoracic duct in an animal model. In this study, they used indocyanine green to stain the thoracic duct to enable the macroscopic detection of even small amounts of leakage. They demonstrated that the sealed end could resist pressures up to 188 mm Hg. In the human, the estimated intraductal pressure of the lymphatic system ranges from 10 to 25 cm H2O and can rise to 100 mm Hg if the proximal vessels are occluded.25 As a result, lymphatic ducts sealed by the HS are not expected to rupture, even with increased intraductal pressures.24 These 2 studies form a basis for the clinical use of the HS for lymphatic dissection.

There are also a number of studies reporting the use of the HS for axillary lymphatic dissections. These studies, in general, have shown a reduction in operative time, duration of drainage, and seroma formation with the use of the HS versus electrocautery and knot tying.26,27

In our series, the HS was used in a minority of the reoperative cases. This was mostly a result of the fact that the extent of dissection was limited in these patients. Owing to our growing experience, we have started using the HS more frequently for these cases as well.

Even though electrosurgical techniques facilitate dissection and control of small blood vessels, insufficient sealing of small lymphatic vessels may result in postoperative lymphatic leakage. In our study, although we showed a reduction in drainage with the HS, we did not demonstrate a difference in the duration of drainage. We believe that this is related to the retrospective nature of the study because the time of drain removal was not uniform but depended on factors such as scheduling in our practice.

We believe that operative time in neck surgery also depends on surgeon experience and extent of pathology, as shown in our study for MRND. Multivariate analyses should be done when comparing operative time between different surgical techniques.

In conclusion, we report an advantage of the HS when compared with knot tying for reducing lymphatic drainage in MRND for thyroid cancer. Future studies controlling for the experience of the surgeon and extent of pathology are necessary to elucidate the effect of the HS on operative time.
